title: 106_hr5082
content: The Act may be cited as the "Local Participation in Railroad Operations Act" and includes provisions for local input. The "Local Participation in Railroad Operations Act" amends Chapter 109 of title 49, United States Code by adding a new section requiring rail carriers to provide notice, hold public hearings, and address concerns before constructing or expanding railroad facilities. The Board will regulate appropriate notice within 6 months of enactment. The Board will regulate appropriate notice procedures under various circumstances, including emergencies, within 6 months of enactment. SEC. 3. PUBLIC MEETINGS. The Secretary of Transportation must convene public meetings annually to address quality of life and safety issues near railroad tracks. Meetings will be held in diverse locations to identify solutions, with a focus on participation from local officials and relevant stakeholders. The Secretary of Transportation must convene public meetings annually with various stakeholders to address safety and quality of life near railroad tracks. A report summarizing the results and recommendations for Congress must be submitted within 3 months after each round of meetings. SEC. 4 amends Section 11324 of title 49, United States Code, requiring the Board to ensure rail carriers address quality of life and safety concerns for residents near railroad tracks in transactions. SEC. 5 focuses on regulations to reduce noise pollution along railroad lines. Within 6 months of this Act's enactment, the EPA Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, must publish proposed regulations in the Federal Register to reduce noise pollution from railroad operations. The regulations aim to protect public health and welfare, especially those living or working near railroad tracks, considering noise reduction technology and compliance costs. Safety considerations from title 49, United States Code, must be strongly considered to ensure public safety is not compromised. The Administrator must promulgate final regulations within 90 days of publishing proposed regulations to reduce noise pollution from railroad operations. These regulations will replace any Federal railroad-related noise regulations for locomotives and rail cars and may be revised as needed. Upon issuance of final regulations, section 17 of the Noise Control Act of 1972 will be repealed.
